title.rendered: Master the Art of Buyer Meetings: Step-by-Step Rapport Building Guide

content.rendered:
Podcast: Play in new window | Download (Duration: 16:41 — 15.3MB)

Subscribe: Spotify | Email | RSS

Congratulations! You’ve made it through the first four steps of successfully acquiring an e-commerce business to scale your brand. Here’s a quick recap:

  1. Decide to Buy: Defined your goals and motivations for acquisition.
  2. Define Your Ideal Target Business: Identified the type of business that aligns with your vision.
  3. Find Your Ideal Businesses (Deal Flow): Utilized various strategies to discover potential acquisition targets.
  4. Filter Your Suspects to Prospects: Narrowed down your options to qualified candidates.

Now comes a crucial step: the buyer meeting. This is your chance to connect with the seller, build rapport, evaluate the business, and set the stage for a successful acquisition. This guide will equip you with the tools and strategies to navigate this pivotal step.

Time Stamp

[00:44] – Introduction To 10 Step Process For Acquiring E-commerce Business
[01:03] – Recap Of Previous Steps
[01:59] – Four Aims Of Step Five
[02:43] – Importance Of Building Rapport
[03:42] – Evaluating The Business
[04:42] – Preparation Before The Meeting
[05:30] – Researching The Business And Owner
[06:30] – Basics For The Meeting: Dress Code And Punctuality
[07:45] – Managing Meeting Time
[08:44] – Main Aim In The Meeting: Building Rapport
[09:31] – Active Listening Techniques
[10:48] – Balancing Professionalism And Friendliness
[11:27] – Presenting Your Own Value
[12:26] – Positioning Yourself As An Experienced Dealmaker
[13:20] – Offer To Review Potential Deals
[13:35] – Importance Of First Impressions And Rapport Building
[14:39] – Practice Makes Perfect: Role Playing And Reflection
[15:14] – Offer For Assistance In Business Buying Process
[16:32] – Preview Of Next Episode: Six Killer Questions

Aims of this Step in the Process:

  • Building Rapport: Create a connection and establish trust with the seller.
  • Positioning Yourself as an Expert/Safe Pair of Hands: Demonstrate your knowledge and capability to manage the business.
  • Evaluating the Business: Gain a deeper understanding of the company’s strengths and weaknesses.
  • Setting Up Next Steps: Determine a clear path forward for moving towards acquisition talks.

Overview of the Process:

This section will delve into the key aspects of your buyer meeting:

  • Preparation: How to gather information and prepare yourself for the encounter.
  • Setting the Right Tone: Ensuring professionalism and creating a comfortable environment.
  • Building Rapport: Techniques to connect with the seller on a personal level.
  • Evaluating the Business: Strategies for acquiring a basic understanding of the company’s performance.
  • Setting Up Next Steps: Establishing a clear plan for moving forward.

Preparation (3 minutes):

Before the meeting, thorough preparation is key. Here’s how to hit the ground running:

A. Researching the Business and Owner:

  • Owner:
    • LinkedIn: Explore their experience, network, and any connections you might share.
    • Google: Look for news articles, interviews, or past ventures that demonstrate their expertise.
    • Facebook: Gain insights into their interests and personality (optional).
  • Business:
    • Amazon: Analyze the listings, pricing strategy, reviews, and customer engagement.
    • Ecom/Brand Site: Explore the brand messaging, product variety, and overall customer experience.
    • Social Media (e.g., Instagram): Observe the brand personality, visuals, and customer interaction.

B. Identifying Common Interests or Experiences:

The goal here is to find common ground:

  • Shared hobbies (sports teams, etc.)
  • Geographical similarities (grew up in the same area, state, etc.)
  • Educational background (same university, mastermind groups, etc.)
  • Industry connections (knowing common industry figures)

Understanding the Business’s Aims:

While researching, also demonstrate your knowledge of the business:

  • Analyze current trends in the industry/sub-industry/category.
  • Use tools like Helium 10 or Jungle Scout to assess competitor performance.
  • Consider purchasing the company’s hero product to gain firsthand experience. Bringing it to the meeting can even be a great conversation starter.

C. Understanding the Industry (or Sub-Industry/Category):

Doing basic industry research helps you:

  • Identify top players and market trends.
  • Utilize tools like Helium 10 or Jungle Scout for further analysis.
  • Purchase the business’s hero product to experience it firsthand.

Setting the Right Tone (3 minutes):

First impressions matter:

A. Dressing Appropriately for the Meeting:

While casual attire can be acceptable for certain scenarios, it’s generally best to err on the side of formality.

Rule of thumb: The older the seller, the more formal your attire should be.

B. Being Punctual and Respectful of Their Time:

Check traffic conditions beforehand.

For virtual meetings, leave a buffer in your schedule to avoid last-minute delays.

C. Finishing on Time (or Checking if They’re Okay to Continue):

Set an end time for the meeting beforehand. If you click with the seller and the conversation flows, politely ask if they’re comfortable extending the meeting. However, be mindful of their time and don’t overstay your welcome.

IN THE MEETING:

Building Rapport (3 minutes):

A. Why Rapport Matters in Business Acquisitions:

Building rapport is crucial in business acquisitions for several reasons:

  • Trust: It fosters a sense of trust and confidence, which is essential for successful negotiations.
  • Communication: It creates a more open and honest communication environment.
  • Collaboration: It facilitates a collaborative approach to problem-solving and decision-making.
  • Negotiations: It can lead to more favorable terms and conditions.

B. How to Build Rapport Effectively:

  • Active Listening: Show genuine interest in what the seller is saying by maintaining eye contact, nodding, and asking follow-up questions.
  • Finding Common Ground: Identify shared interests, experiences, or values to create a connection.
  • Showing Genuine Interest: Ask questions that demonstrate your curiosity and enthusiasm about the business.
  • Asking Follow-Up Questions: Show engagement by asking follow-up questions to delve deeper into specific topics.
  • Avoiding Interruptions: Allow the seller to finish speaking without interrupting.
  • Balancing Professionalism and Friendliness: Be polite, respectful, and approachable, but maintain a professional demeanor.

A. Recap of Key Points:

  • Summarize the main points discussed during the meeting.
  • Highlight the common ground you found and the areas where you see potential alignment.

B. Preview of Next Episode:

Mention the upcoming episode, “What to Ask When Buying a Business: 6 Killer Questions (Step 5).”

Visit our website for more information on your Amazon audit.
